 Serif&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;u&gt;Note 5 - Contingencies&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;u&gt;Note&#13;6 - Litigation&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;The Company is engaged in various&#13;legal actions, claims and proceedings arising in the normal course of business, including claims related to breach of contracts,&#13;product liabilities and intellectual property matters resulting from the Company&amp;#146;s business activities. As with most actions&#13;such as these, an estimation of any possible and/or ultimate liability cannot always be determined. The following summaries highlight&#13;the current status of certain material commercial litigation in which the Company is involved.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;D. Tawnsaura brought a class&#13;action complaint against the Company and 56 other retailers/distributors for infringement of a patented ingredient &amp;#147;Citrulline&#13;Malate&amp;#148;. This ingredient is utilized by the Company in certain of its product formulations. The court ordered the plaintiffs&#13;to resubmit their complaint and make it legally sufficient, which occurred on October 31, 2012. As result of two developments&#13;in this case; 1) the Court&amp;#146;s construction of the term &amp;#147;L-citrulline&amp;#148; (in the 107 patent) to include citrulline&#13;malate and 2) the defendants&amp;#146; new assertion of &amp;#147;inequitable conduct stemming from the inventor&amp;#146;s withholding&#13;important prior art and other relevant information from disclosure to the Patent and Trademark Office, &amp;#147;PTO&amp;#148;, the&#13;plaintiff has requested to the PTO an &amp;#147;ex parte reexamination&amp;#148; of the 107 patent. The Company and many of the other&#13;defendants are contesting the alleged patent position of the plaintiff; accordingly, all parties in this matter have filed a motion&#13;to stay the entire case until the PTO has ruled on the plaintiff&amp;#146;s request. During November 2013 a settlement was reached&#13;between Tawnsaura and the Company and a patent utilization arrangement was reached and the suit was dismissed.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;u&gt;Note&#13;7 - Income Taxes&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;For the year ended December 31&#13;2013, the Company recognized income tax expense of $2,828. For the year ended December 31 2012, the Company recognized income&#13;tax benefit of $737, which reflects the adjustment of the above mentioned net tax asset in the amount of $67,083, offset by the&#13;net tax expense of the year totaling $66,346.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;At December 31, 2013 and 2012,&#13;management believes there are no uncertain tax liabilities. The Company recognizes interest and penalties related to uncertain&#13;tax positions in income tax (benefit)/expense. No interest and penalties related to uncertain tax positions were accrued at December&#13;31, 2013 or 2012.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;The Company files income tax returns in U.S. federal&#13;jurisdiction and various states. There are currently no federal or state income tax examinations underway for these jurisdictions.&#13;The 2013 tax year remains open to examination by taxing jurisdictions to which the Company is subject.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;Income tax provision for the&#13;periods December 31, 2013 and December 31, 2012 consists of the following:&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style=width: 100%; margin-top: 0px; font-size: 9pt&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style=font-size: 1pt&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 77%&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times

 Times

 Serif&gt;(116,534)&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style=vertical-align: bottom&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=text-indent: 48px&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman

 Serif&gt;Net Deferred tax asset&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: #000000 3px double&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman

 Serif&gt;$&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: #000000 3px double; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman

 Serif&gt;201,022&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman

 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: #000000 3px double&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman

 Serif&gt;$&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: #000000 3px double; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;216,876&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;/table&gt;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;As of December 31, 2013, the Company has federal and&#13;state income tax net operating loss (NOL) carryforwards of $1,079,046 which will expire at various dates from 2032 through 2033.&#13;The NOLs are projected to expire as follows:&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=margin: 0&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style=width: 100%; margin-top: 0px; font-size: 9pt&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style=font-size: 1pt&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 28%&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 51%&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 2%&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 19%&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=background-color: #f3f3f3; vertical-align: bottom; text-align: center&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;2032&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=background-color: #f3f3f3; vertical-align: bottom&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=background-color: #f3f3f3; vertical-align: top&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;$&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=background-color: #f3f3f3; vertical-align: bottom; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;434,814&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=vertical-align: bottom; text-align: center&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;2033&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=vertical-align: bottom&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman

 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=vertical-align: top&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman

 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=vertical-align: bottom; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;644,232&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style=background-color: #f3f3f3&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=vertical-align: bottom&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman

 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=vertical-align: bottom&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: #000000 3px double; border-top: #000000 1px solid; vertical-align: top&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: #000000 3px double; border-top: #000000 1px solid; vertical-align: bottom; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;1,079,046&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;/table&gt;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;NOL from Predecessor Company&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: center; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;At December 31, 2013, approximately&#13;$8.208 million of net operating loss carryforwards for federal income tax purposes and approximately $8.208 million of net operating&#13;loss carryforwards for state income tax purposes, existed and were previously generated by a predecessor company. The Tax Reform&#13;Act of 1986 contains provisions that limit the utilization of net operating loss and tax credit carryforwards if there has been&#13;a change of ownership as described in Section 382 of the Internal Revenue Code. According to a preliminary analysis performed&#13;by the Company, it was determined that these net operating loss carryforwards would not currently be available for utilization&#13;by the Company. As such, these net operating loss carryforwards which had previously been 100% allowed for, have been removed&#13;from the deferred tax assets. The availability of the net operating loss carryforwards may be analyzed further in future accounting&#13;periods. If a positive determination is made, the net operating loss carryforwards might then be reported as deferred tax assets&#13;of the Company.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;NOL from iSatori&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;Based upon past financial performance,&#13;the company has not been able to utilize certain NOL carryforwards. In recognition of this risk, a valuation allowance of $410,140&#13;has been provided on the deferred tax assets relating to the NOL carryforwards. Should future financial performance change and&#13;it is determined the company can realize the use of these NOLs, the appropriate tax expense and equity adjustments will be made.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times

 Serif&gt;(116,534)&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style=vertical-align: bottom&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=text-indent: 48px&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman

 Serif&gt;201,022&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman

&lt;table cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style=width: 100%; margin-top: 0px; font-size: 9pt&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style=font-size: 1pt&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 28%&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 51%&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman

 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 2%&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 19%&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=background-color: #f3f3f3; vertical-align: bottom; text-align: center&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;2032&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=background-color: #f3f3f3; vertical-align: bottom&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=background-color: #f3f3f3; vertical-align: top&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;$&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=background-color: #f3f3f3; vertical-align: bottom; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;434,814&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=vertical-align: bottom; text-align: center&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;2033&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=vertical-align: bottom&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=vertical-align: top&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=vertical-align: bottom; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;644,232&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style=background-color: #f3f3f3&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=vertical-align: bottom&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=vertical-align: bottom&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: #000000 3px double; border-top: #000000 1px solid; vertical-align: top&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: #000000 3px double; border-top: #000000 1px solid; vertical-align: bottom; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;u&gt;Note&#13;8 - Stockholders&amp;#146; Equity&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;At December 31, 2013, there were&#13;12,879,651 shares of common stock, par value $.01 per share, outstanding for the Company.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;Effective February 16, 2012,&#13;in connection with the $250,000 Convertible Promissory Note dated October 15, 2010 between the Company and James and Kristin Black,&#13;the Company exchanged 493,252 Common Shares of stock for the cancellation of the Note Payable. In accordance with the terms of&#13;the Merger, the total number of shares was reduced to 329,502.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&lt;i&gt;Warrant Grants&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;As of December 31, 2013, there&#13;were common stock warrants outstanding to purchase aggregate shares of common stock pursuant to the warrant grants described below.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;On November 1, 2010, the&#13;Company issued warrants to purchase 150,000 shares of the common stock of the Company to Transition Partners, Limited with a&#13;an indeterminable exercise price per share in connection with a consulting services agreement. These warrants were subject to&#13;a conditional vesting schedule, in one-third increments. As of December 31, 2010, the first 50,000 of these warrants were&#13;fully vested and were due to expire on November 1, 2013. On June 17, 2011, the second 50,000 of these warrants were fully&#13;vested and due to expire on November 1, 2013. On April 6, 2012 the third 50,000 of these warrants were fully vested and were&#13;due to expire on November 1, 2013. Upon completion of and in accordance with the terms of the Merger, the total number of&#13;warrants to purchase such shares was reduced to 123,563 and the per share exercise price was fixed at $0.57 per share. In&#13;addition, the expiration of the warrants was extended to July 31, 2015. These warrants were exercised in two installments on&#13;May 29, and June 20, 2013, using a cashless exercise method based on the closing share price on that date, resulting in the&#13;issuance of 103,762 shares of common stock.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;On June 17, 2011 the Company&#13;also issued warrants to purchase 50,000 shares of the common stock of the Company to AVIDBank Corporate Finance, a division of&#13;AVIDBank, with an exercise price equal to one-hundredth of a dollar in connection with the $1.0 million revolving line of credit&#13;arrangement (See Note 10, Revolving Lines of Credit and Related Interest). These warrants are fully vested and expire on June&#13;17, 2016. Upon completion of the Merger, the total number of warrants to purchase such shares was reduced to 33,401 and the per&#13;share exercise price remained the same. These warrants were exercised in full on June 28, 2013, and 33,401 shares of common stock&#13;were issued to AVIDBank.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;On July 15, 2011 the Company&#13;issued warrants to purchase 3% of fully diluted shares of the common stock of the Company to Breakwater Structured Growth Opportunity&#13;Fund, L.P., with an imputed exercise price equal to approximately one-hundredth of a dollar in connection with the $1.025 million&#13;subordinated mezzanine loan arrangement (See Note 9, Long Term Indebtedness and Interest). These warrants are fully vested and&#13;expire on June 15, 2016. In accordance with the terms of the Merger, the total number of warrants to purchase such shares was&#13;increased from 328,411 shares to 420,549 and the per share exercise price remained the same.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;Included in the aforementioned&#13;Breakwater warrant, was an obligation by the Company to, among other things, honor an irrevocable put right through which the&#13;Company agreed to purchase up to the 3% of fully diluted shares of its common stock underlying the warrant, which expires on July&#13;15, 2016 (See Note 9, Long Term Indebtedness and Interest). Upon completion of the Merger, the irrevocable put right was removed.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;The Company applied fair value&#13;accounting for all share based payments awards. The fair value of each warrant granted is estimated each quarter using the Binomial&#13;Lattice Model option-pricing model. These valuations resulted in net income of $143,082 in the Statement of Operations for the&#13;twelve month period ended December 31, 2013. In addition, as of June 28, 2013, $87,755 was reclassified to additional paid in&#13;capital from derivative liability due to the exercise of the AVIDBank warrant.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; text-indent: 0px; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&lt;i&gt;February&#13;2012 Management Options&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;Effective February 16, 2012,&#13;the Company issued options to purchase 1,233,129 shares of the Company stock to eight management employees, having an initial&#13;exercise price of $0.38, and which contain various vesting schedules and expiration dates. Upon completion of the merger, the&#13;total number of options to purchase such shares was reduced to 823,757 and the per share exercise price was correspondingly adjusted&#13;to $0.573 per share in accordance with the terms of the Merger Agreement. In 2012, one management employee left prior to vesting,&#13;forfeiting the option to purchase 50,102 shares.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;The Company applied fair value&#13;accounting for all share based payments awards. The fair value of each option granted is estimated on the date of grant using&#13;the Black-Scholes option-pricing model, for a total valuation of $56,799, which is the net of the $61,495 which was expensed in&#13;full on the date of the grant less the $4,696 which was later reversed upon the forfeiture of the option to purchase 50,102 shares.&#13;The Black-Scholes assumptions used when the options were issued in the year ended December 31, 2012 are as follows:&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style=width: 100%; margin-top: 0px; font-size: 9pt&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style=font-size: 1pt&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 88%&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 1%&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 9%&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 2%&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=background-color: #f3f3f3; vertical-align: bottom&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;Exercise&#13;    price&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=background-color: #f3f3f3; vertical-align: bottom&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;$&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=background-color: #f3f3f3; vertical-align: bottom; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;0.383&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=background-color: #f3f3f3; vertical-align: bottom&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style=vertical-align: bottom&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman

 Serif&gt;%&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style=vertical-align: bottom; background-color: #f3f3f3&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman

 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman

 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;/table&gt;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; text-indent: 0px; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&lt;i&gt;2012 Performance&#13;Incentive Plan&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;On September 27, 2012, the Company&amp;#146;s&#13;Board of Directors approved the 2012 Performance Incentive Plan (the Plan&amp;#148;). The Plan allows the Company to promote the&#13;success of the Corporation and to increase stockholder value by providing an additional means through the grant of awards to attract,&#13;motivate, retain and reward selected employees and other eligible persons. Any stock option granted in the form of an incentive&#13;stock option will be intended to comply with the&lt;font style=color: #00007f&gt; &lt;/font&gt;requirements of Section 422 of the Code.&#13;Only stock options granted to employees qualify for incentive stock option treatment. A stock option may be exercised in whole&#13;or in installments, which may be cumulative. Shares of common stock purchased upon the exercise of a stock option must be paid&#13;for in full at the time of the exercise in cash or such other consideration determined by the compensation committee. Payment&#13;may include tendering shares of common stock or surrendering of a stock award, or a combination of methods.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;The Plan is administered by the&#13;Plan Administrator, being the Board or one or more committees appointed by the Board or another committee (within its delegated&#13;authority) to administer all or certain aspects of this Plan. The Administrator has full and exclusive power within the limitations&#13;set forth in the Plan to make all decisions and determinations regarding the selection of participants and the granting of awards;&#13;establishing the terms and conditions relating to each award; adopting rules, regulations and guidelines; and interpreting the&#13;Plan.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;On September 28, 2012, the Company&#13;issued options to purchase 54,479 shares of the Company stock to ten employees, having an exercise price of $2.25, and which contain&#13;three year vesting schedules of 1/3 each year through September 2015. These options are due to expire on September 27, 2022.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;On September 17, 2013, the Company&#13;issued options to purchase 50,000 shares of the Company stock to one employee, having an exercise price of $2.10, and which contain&#13;three year vesting schedules of 1/3 each year through September 2015. These options are due to expire on September 17, 2023.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;The Company applied fair value&#13;accounting for all share based payments awards. The fair value of each option granted is estimated on the date of grant using&#13;the Black-Scholes option-pricing model, for a total valuation of $51,978, which will be expensed over the three year vesting period.&#13;The expense realized for the year ending December 31, 2013 was $20,022. The Black-Scholes assumptions used when the options were&#13;issued in the year ended December 31, 2012 are as follows:&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style=width: 100%; margin-top: 0px; font-size: 9pt&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style=font-size: 1pt&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 55%&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times

 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;/table&gt;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; text-indent: 0px; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&lt;i&gt;Contractor&#13;Warrant and Option&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;On September 6, 2012, the Company&#13;entered into a one year investor relations consulting contract with RJ Falkner &amp;#38; Company, Inc (&amp;#147;RJ Falkner&amp;#148;),&#13;which includes a grant to R. Jerry Falkner, the owner of RJ Falkner, as an individual, a five year option to purchase 125,000&#13;of share of common stock and an exercise price of $2.25 per share. These options were subject to a conditional vesting schedule,&#13;in one-fourth increments. The first installment vested and became exercisable upon execution of the consulting contract on September&#13;6, 2012. The second installment upon the publication of the first &amp;#147;Research Profile&amp;#148; report, which was completed November&#13;30, 2012, The third and fourth installments vested at 90 and 180 days following the publication of the aforementioned report.&#13;As of December 31, 2013, all four increments were fully vested for a total of 125,000 shares are due to expire on September 5,&#13;2017.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;Effective November 30, 2012,&#13;the Company issued options to purchase 100,000 shares of the Company&amp;#146;s common stock to two consultants with an exercise&#13;price of $2.50 per share and were subject to a three year vesting schedule, in one-third increments. The first vesting period&#13;begins on November 30, 2013. These options are due to expire on November 30, 2022.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;Effective January 1, 2013, the&#13;Company entered into a one year agreement, subject to quarterly cancellation at the Company&amp;#146;s sole discretion, with Microcap&#13;Headlines, Inc. In connection with this agreement, the Company issued warrants to purchase an aggregate of 100,000 shares of the&#13;Company&amp;#146;s common stock at an exercise price of $2.25 per share. These warrants were subject to conditional vesting schedule&#13;in one-fourth (quarterly) increments, subject to the Company&amp;#146;s sole discretion. The first increment was granted and fully&#13;vested on January 1, 2013, the second increment was granted and fully vested on April 1, 2013, the third increment was granted&#13;and fully vested on July 1, 2013, and the forth increment was granted and fully vested on October 1, 2013. All vested warrants&#13;expire on January 1, 2018.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;Effective July 16, 2013, the Company entered into&#13;an business consulting agreement with Optivest Global Partners, LLC. In connection with this agreement, the Company issued warrants&#13;to purchase an aggregate of 250,000 shares of the Company&amp;#146;s common stock at an exercise price of $2.25 per share. These&#13;warrants are fully vested and expire July 16, 2018. These warrants will be assignable and transferable, at Optivest&amp;#146;s discretion.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;The Company applied fair value&#13;accounting for all share based payments awards. The fair value of each option or warrant granted is estimated on the date of grant&#13;using the Black-Scholes option-pricing model. These valuations resulted in an net expense of $300,026 in the Statement of Operations&#13;for the twelve month period ended December 31, 2013.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;The Black-Scholes assumptions&#13;used when the options or warrant were issued in the year ended December 31, 2013 are as follows:&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style=width: 100%; margin-top: 0px; font-size: 9pt&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style=font-size: 1pt&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 69%&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times

 Serif&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;u&gt;Note 9 - CONVERTIBLE PREFERRED&#13;STOCK&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman

 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;In connection with the Merger,&#13;the Company assumed into its capital structure the convertible stock originally issued by Integrated. Accordingly, at December&#13;31, 2013, the Company&amp;#146;s convertible preferred stock, $0.01 par value per share, consisted of the following:&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style=width: 100%; margin-top: 0px; font-size: 10pt&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style=font-size: 1pt&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 50%&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times

 Times
 Serif&gt;450,000&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;/table&gt;&#13;&lt;p style=margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;Series A $20 Convertible Preferred Stock. At December&#13;31, 2013, the Company had 9,500 shares of its Series A $20 Convertible Preferred Stock (the &amp;#147;Series A Preferred&amp;#148;)&#13;outstanding. Holders of the Series A Preferred are not entitled to receive any dividends, and have no voting rights unless otherwise&#13;required pursuant to Delaware law. Each share of the Series A Preferred may, at the option of the Company, be converted into the&#13;equivalent of one-fifth (1/5th) of a share of common stock at any time after (i) the closing bid price of the common stock is&#13;at least $2.00 for at least 20 trading days during any 30 consecutive trading day period, and (ii) the shares of common stock&#13;to be received on conversion have been registered or otherwise qualified for sale under applicable securities laws. The holders&#13;of the Series A Preferred have the right to convert each share into the equivalent of one-fifth (1/5th) of a share of common stock&#13;at any time. Upon any liquidation, dissolution, or winding up of the Company, the holders of the Series A Preferred are entitled&#13;to receive $20 per share before the holders of common stock are entitled to receive any distribution. In the event the Company&#13;enters into any consolidation, merger or other transaction in which the shares of Common Stock are exchanged for or changed into&#13;other stock or other securities, each share of Series A Preferred will at the same time be similarly exchanged or changed into&#13;such consideration as is equal to four times the amount of consideration to be received for each share of common stock.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;Series D $20 Convertible Preferred&#13;Stock. At December 31, 2013 the Company had 13,000 shares of its Series D $20 Convertible Preferred Stock (the &amp;#147;Series D&#13;Preferred&amp;#148;) outstanding. Holders of the Series D Preferred are entitled to receive, out of funds of the Company legally&#13;available, dividends at the annual rate of $1.80 per annum per share.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times

 Serif&gt;&lt;b&gt;Par&#13;    Value&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=vertical-align: bottom&gt;&lt;font style=font: 8pt Times New Roman

 Serif&gt;&lt;b&gt;Shares&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;        &lt;p style=font-size: 8.5pt; text-align: center; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 8pt Times New Roman

 Serif&gt;&lt;b&gt;Outstanding&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=vertical-align: bottom&gt;&lt;font style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td colspan=2 style=border-bottom: #000000 1px solid; vertical-align: bottom&gt;&lt;p style=font-size: 8.5pt; text-align: center; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 8pt Times New Roman

 Serif&gt;&lt;b&gt;Liquidation&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;        &lt;p style=font-size: 8.5pt; text-align: center; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&lt;b&gt;Preference&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style=vertical-align: bottom; background-color: #f3f3f3&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=font-size: 9pt&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times

 Serif&gt;260,000&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style=vertical-align: bottom; background-color: #f3f3f3&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman

 Serif&gt;22,500&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman

 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=font-size: 9pt&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman

&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman

 Serif&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;u&gt;Note&#13;10 - Revolving Line of Credit and Related Interest&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;The Company entered into a Credit&#13;Agreement with Colorado Business Bank West of Denver, Colorado on July 16, 2012, and in connection with the entrance into the&#13;New Credit Agreement, terminated its commitments under its existing credit agreement with Avidbank Corporate Finance, a division&#13;of AvidBank. Borrowings under this agreement will be used to provide ongoing working capital and for other general corporate purposes&#13;of the Company and its subsidiaries.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;The agreement provides a revolving&#13;commitment to the Company of $1,500,000, which increased the Company&amp;#146;s previous borrowing capacity by fifty percent. Amounts&#13;outstanding under the agreement will be reflected in a promissory note with a principal balance of $1,500,000 and a maturity date&#13;of July 16, 2013 (the &amp;#147;Promissory Note&amp;#148;). The principal balance on the Promissory Note will bear interest at the one&#13;month USD LIBOR rate measured not more often than once per month (the &amp;#147;Index&amp;#148;). Interest on any unpaid balance under&#13;the promissory note will bear interest at the Index plus 3.750% with a minimum interest rate of 4.000% per annum.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;u&gt;Note&#13;11 - Long-Term Indebtedness and Interest&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;In October, 2010, the Company&#13;entered into a $250,000 long-term debt arrangement (the &amp;#147;Note&amp;#148;) with an unrelated private investor, with interest&#13;due monthly at the rate equal to 10%. The principal amount of the Note was required by the Predecessor Company to be repaid in&#13;full on its first anniversary. However, at that time, if the Predecessor Company had not entered into a satisfactory subsequent&#13;financing arrangement, in the sole discretion of the investor, the $250,000 Note could be immediately called and would be due&#13;and payable. The holder of the Note had the option to then either convert the Note into a three-year term loan or convert the&#13;Note into shares of common stock in the Predecessor Company. The holder of the Note had 15 months from the first anniversary of&#13;the making of the Note to make this decision, that is, until December 31, 2012. Subsequently, in February, 2012, the Note holder&#13;agreed that all previous new financing contingencies had been met and consented to convert the Note into 493,252 shares of common&#13;stock of the Company in complete and total satisfaction of the Note. In accordance with the terms of the Merger, the total number&#13;of shares was reduced to 329,502.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;u&gt;Note&#13;12 - Fair Value Measurements and Disclosures&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;The Company follows ASC 820,&#13;Fair Value Measurements and Disclosures, which defines fair value, establishes a framework for using fair value to measure assets&#13;and liabilities, and expands disclosures about fair value measurements. The statement establishes a hierarchy for inputs used&#13;in measuring fair value that maximizes the use of observable inputs and minimizes the use of unobservable inputs by requiring&#13;that the most observable inputs be used when available. Observable inputs are inputs that market participants would use in pricing&#13;the asset or liability developed based on market data obtained from sources independent of the Company. Unobservable inputs are&#13;inputs that reflect the Company&amp;#146;s assumptions of what market participants would use in pricing the asset or liability developed&#13;based on the best information available in the circumstances. The hierarchy is broken down into three levels based on the reliability&#13;of the inputs as follows:&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;Level 1: Quoted prices are available&#13;in active markets for identical assets or liabilities.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;Level 2: Quoted prices in active&#13;markets for similar assets and liabilities that are observable for the asset or liability; or&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;Level 3: Unobservable pricing&#13;inputs that are generally less observable from objective sources, such as discounted cash flow models or valuations.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;ASC 820 requires financial assets&#13;and liabilities to be classified based on the lowest level of input that is significant to the fair value measurement. The Company&amp;#146;s&#13;assessment of the significance of a particular input to the fair value measurement requires judgment, and may affect the valuation&#13;of the fair value of assets and liabilities and their placement within the fair value hierarchy levels.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;For the purposes of marketable&#13;securities where there is a an active market, the Company uses the quoted prices available for the identical asset or liability.&#13;As of December 31, 2012, the Company had $965,886 in a highly liquid investment account and $29,338 assets held for sale valued&#13;using the Level 1 mark-to-market approach. As of December 31, 2013, the Company had $108,228 assets held for sale valued using&#13;the Level 1 mark-to-market approach.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;The inputs used in the fair value&#13;measurements categorized within Level 3 include the stock price at the valuation date, the exercise price of the warrant, the&#13;expected period of time the warrant will be outstanding, the annual volatility of the underlying stock price, the annual yield&#13;rate of quarterly dividends, and the risk free rate of interest relevant to the expected time period the warrant will be outstanding.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;The following table represents&#13;the Company&amp;#146;s warrant derivative liabilities that were accounted for at fair value on a recurring basis by level within&#13;the fair value hierarchy:&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=margin: 0&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style=margin-top: 0px; font-size: 9pt; width: 100%&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style=font-size: 1pt&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 7px&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 56px&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 7px&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 7px&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 56px&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times

 Times

 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 7px&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times

 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 55px&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 7px&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 7px&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman

 at the option of the Company
 be converted into the equivalent of one-fifth (1/5th) of a share of common stock at any time after (i) the closing bid price of the common stock is at least $2.00 for at least 20 trading days during any 30 consecutive trading day period
 and (ii) the shares of common stock to be received on conversion have been registered or otherwise qualified for sale under applicable securities laws. The holders of the Series A Preferred have the right to convert each share into the equivalent of one-fifth (1/5th) of a share of common stock at any time. Upon any liquidation
 dissolution
 or winding up of the Company
 the holders of the Series A Preferred are entitled to receive $20 per share before the holders of common stock are entitled to receive any distribution. In the event the Company enters into any consolidation
 merger or other transaction in which the shares of Common Stock are exchanged for or changed into other stock or other securities
 each share of Series A Preferred will at the same time be similarly exchanged or changed into such consideration as is equal to four times the amount of consideration to be received for each share of common stock. Holders of the Series D Preferred are entitled to receive
 out of funds of the company legally available
 dividends at the annual rate of $1.80 per annum per share. The Company may redeem the Series D Preferred upon not less than 30 days' notice
 in whole or in part
 for an amount of $20 per share plus all accrued but unpaid dividends applicable to such share. After notice and prior to the expiration of the 30-day notice period
 holders of the Series D Preferred will have the option to convert the Series D Preferred into common stock prior to the redemption. Each share of the Series D Preferred may
 at the option of the Company
 be converted into the number of shares of common stock as determined by dividing $20 plus any accrued and unpaid dividends on such share by $80 at any time after (i) the closing bid price of the common stock exceeds $200.00 for 20 consecutive trading days
 and (ii) the Company has sustained positive earnings per share of common stock for the two previous fiscal quarters. The holders of the Series D Preferred have the right to convert each share at any time into the number of shares of common stock as determined by dividing $20 plus any accrued and unpaid dividends on such share by $80. The holders of the Series D Preferred are entitled to receive $20 per share plus any accrued and unpaid dividends on such share before the holders of common stock are entitled to receive any distribution. In the event the Company enters into any consolidation
 merger or other transaction in which the shares of Common Stock are exchanged for or changed into other stock or other securities
 each share of Series D Preferred will at the same time be similarly exchanged or changed into the aggregate amount of stock as would have been received had the holder converted such shares immediately prior to the transaction.




        
          

        
          
            

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    








        
          

        
          
            

 exercise (or conversion) price or rates
 dates relevant to conversion timing and events relevant to conversion. Describe also any beneficial conversion features. where convertible preferred stock with a nondetachable conversion feature is in-the-money at commitment date. For contingently convertible preferred stock
 discuss the circumstances of the contingency
 including the events or changes in circumstance that would cause the contingency to be met and any of the significant features necessary to understand the conversion rights and the timing of those rights. Include also an events or changes in circumstance
 if any
 that could adjust or change the contingency
 conversion price
 or number of shares
 including significant terms of those changes.

/* Updated 2009-11-04 */
/* v2.2.0.24 */
/* DefRef Styles */
..report table.authRefData{
	background-color: #def;
	border: 2px solid #2F4497;
	font-size: 1em;
	position: absolute;
}
..report table.authRefData a {
	display: block;
	font-weight: bold;
}
..report table.authRefData p {
	margin-top: 0px;
}
..report table.authRefData .hide {
	background-color: #2F4497;
	padding: 1px 3px 0px 0px;
	text-align: right;
}
..report table.authRefData .hide a:hover {
	background-color: #2F4497;
}
..report table.authRefData .body {
	height: 150px;
	overflow: auto;
	width: 400px;
}
..report table.authRefData table{
	font-size: 1em;
}
/* Report Styles */
..pl a
 .pl a:visited {
	color: black;
	text-decoration: none;
}
/* table */
..report {
	background-color: white;
	border: 2px solid #acf;
	clear: both;
	color: black;
	font: normal 8pt Helvetica
 Arial
 san-serif;
	margin-bottom: 2em;
}
..report hr {
	border: 1px solid #acf;
}
/* Top labels */
..report th {
	background-color: #acf;
	color: black;
	font-weight: bold;
	text-align: center;
}
..report th.void	{
	background-color: transparent;
	color: #000000;
	font: bold 10pt Helvetica
 Arial
 san-serif;
	text-align: left;
}
..report .pl {
	text-align: left;
	vertical-align: top;
	white-space: normal;
	width: 200px;
	word-wrap: break-word;
}
..report td.pl a.a {
	cursor: pointer;
	display: block;
	width: 200px;
	overflow: hidden;
}
..report td.pl div.a {
	width: 200px;
}
..report td.pl a:hover {
	background-color: #ffc;
}
/* Header rows... */
..report tr.rh {
	background-color: #acf;
	color: black;
	font-weight: bold;
}
/* Calendars... */
..report .rc {
	background-color: #f0f0f0;
}
/* Even rows... */
..report .re
 .report .reu {
	background-color: #def;
}
..report .reu td {
	border-bottom: 1px solid black;
}
/* Odd rows... */
..report .ro
 .report .rou {
	background-color: white;
}
..report .rou td {
	border-bottom: 1px solid black;
}
..report .rou table td
 .report .reu table td {
	border-bottom: 0px solid black;
}
/* styles for footnote marker */
..report .fn {
	white-space: nowrap;
}
/* styles for numeric types */
..report .num
 .report .nump {
	text-align: right;
	white-space: nowrap;
}
..report .nump {
	padding-left: 2em;
}
..report .nump {
	padding: 0px 0.4em 0px 2em;
}
/* styles for text types */
..report .text {
	text-align: left;
	white-space: normal;
}
..report .text .big {
	margin-bottom: 1em;
	width: 17em;
}
..report .text .more {
	display: none;
}
..report .text .note {
	font-style: italic;
	font-weight: bold;
}
..report .text .small {
	width: 10em;
}
..report sup {
	font-style: italic;
}
..report .outerFootnotes {
	font-size: 1em;
}

 which is a bank's commitment to make loans up to a specific amount. Examples of items that might be included in the application of this element may consist of letters of credit

 under which borrowings can be made up to a maximum amount as of any point in time conditional on satisfaction of specified terms before

 or (b) the enterprise has entered into a financing agreement that clearly permits the enterprise to refinance the short-term obligation on a long term basis and the following conditions are met (1) the agreement does not expire within 1 year and is not cancelable by the lender except for violation of an objectively determinable provision

in an company-sponsored 401(k) plan. New enrollees are able to join the plan in the calendar quarter in which they become eligible.

Note 2 - Endorsement / Spokesperson
/ Consulting Agreements

The Company is obligated under
various endorsement
 spokesperson and consulting agreements with varying original terms ranging from one to three years. These
endorsers
 spokespersons and consultants are generally paid a monthly fee for their services
 including promotion and marketing
activities per the agreements. All of these agreements may be terminated by either party upon breach or default in the terms of
the agreements. The Company expensed $161
950 and $232
248 under these agreements in 2013 and 2012
 respectively.

Future payments of the above mentioned contracts will
run through 2014
 for a total expense of $27
600.

 which is a bank's commitment to make loans up to a specific amount. Examples of items that might be included in the application of this element may consist of letters of credit
 standby letters of credit
 and revolving credit arrangements
 under which borrowings can be made up to a maximum amount as of any point in time conditional on satisfaction of specified terms before
 as of and after the date of drawdowns on the line. Includes short-term obligations that would normally be classified as current liabilities but for which (a) postbalance sheet date issuance of a long term obligation to refinance the short term obligation on a long term basis
 or (b) the enterprise has entered into a financing agreement that clearly permits the enterprise to refinance the short-term obligation on a long term basis and the following conditions are met (1) the agreement does not expire within 1 year and is not cancelable by the lender except for violation of an objectively determinable provision
 (2) no violation exists at the BS date
 and (3) the lender has entered into the financing agreement is expected to be financially capable of honoring the agreement.

 whichever is longer. Such amount may include accrued interest receivable in accordance with the terms of the debt. The debt also may contain provisions including a discount or premium
 payable on demand
 secured
 or unsecured
 interest bearing or noninterest bearing
 among a myriad of other features and characteristics. This amount does not include amounts related to receivables held-for-sale.

/**
 * Rivet Software Inc.
 *
 * @copyright Copyright (c) 2006-2011 Rivet Software
 Inc. All rights reserved.
 * Version 2.4.0.3
 *
 */
var Show = {};
Show.LastAR = null
Show.hideAR = function(){
	Show.LastAR.style.display = 'none';
};
Show.showAR = function ( link
 id
 win ){
	if( Show.LastAR ){
		Show.hideAR();
	}
	var ref = link;
	do {
		ref = ref.nextSibling;
	} while (ref && ref.nodeName != 'TABLE');
	if (!ref || ref.nodeName != 'TABLE') {
		var tmp = win ?
			win.document.getElementById(id) :
			document.getElementById(id);
		if( tmp ){
			ref = tmp.cloneNode(true);
			ref.id = '';
			link.parentNode.appendChild(ref);
		}
	}
	if( ref ){
		ref.style.display = 'block';
		Show.LastAR = ref;
	}
};
Show.toggleNext = function( link ){
	var ref = link;
	do{
		ref = ref.nextSibling;
	}while( ref.nodeName != 'DIV' );
	if( ref.style &&
		ref.style.display &&
		ref.style.display == 'none' ){
		ref.style.display = 'block';
		if( link.textContent ){
			link.textContent = link.textContent.replace( '+'
 '-' );
		}else{
			link.innerText = link.innerText.replace( '+'
 '-' );
		}
	}else{
		ref.style.display = 'none';
		if( link.textContent ){
			link.textContent = link.textContent.replace( '-'
 '+' );
		}else{
			link.innerText = link.innerText.replace( '-'
 '+' );
		}
	}
};











    
  
      

          

        

      






        
        


        
        



iSatori Technologies
 LLC (the
&#147;Predecessor Company&#148;) was formed under the laws of the State of Colorado on June 14
 2004. On June 1
 2011
 LS7 Products
LLC (d/b/a iSatori Global Technologies
 LLC)
 a Colorado limited liability company and wholly owned subsidiary of the Predecessor
Company (&#147;LS7&#148;)
 Eat-Smart
 LLC a Colorado limited liability company and wholly owned subsidiary of the Predecessor
Company (&#147;Eat-Smart&#148;)
 and Energize Solutions
 LLC
 a Colorado limited liability company and wholly owned subsidiary
of the Predecessor Company (&#147;Energize&#148;)
 were merged with and into the Predecessor Company and Right Lane Publishing
Inc.
 a Colorado subchapter S corporation and wholly owned subsidiary of the Predecessor Company (&#147;Right Lane&#148;)
 was
distributed to Stephen Adele Enterprises
 Inc.
 the Predecessor Company&#146;s sole shareholder (collectively
 the &#147;Reorganizations&#148;).
On June 1
 2011
 after consummation of the Reorganizations
 the Predecessor Company converted to a corporation pursuant to the
laws of the State of Colorado changing its name to iSatori Technologies
 Inc. (&#147;iSatori Technologies&#148;).

On April 5
 2012
 iSatori Acquisition
Corp. (&#147;Merger Sub&#148;)
 a Delaware corporation and wholly-owned subsidiary of Integrated Security Systems
 Inc (&#147;Integrated&#148;)
consummated a merger (the &#147;Merger&#148;) with iSatori Technologies
 pursuant to a Merger Agreement
 dated as of February
17
 2012
 by and among Integrated
 Merger Sub and iSatori Technologies (the &#147;Merger Agreement&#148;). Pursuant to the Merger
Agreement
 iSatori Technologies was merged with and into Merger Sub with iSatori Technologies surviving as a wholly-owned subsidiary
of Integrated.

Upon completion of the Merger
the holders of iSatori Technologies&#146; common stock
 and holders of equity instruments convertible into shares of iSatori
Technologies&#146; common stock
 received an aggregate of approximately 8
410
973 shares of Integrated common stock.

On June 29
 2012
 Integrated
completed a &#147;short form&#148; merger under &#167;253 of the Delaware General Corporation Law pursuant to which iSatori
Technologies was merged with and into Integrated with Integrated continuing as the surviving corporation. In connection with the
Merger
 Integrated changed its name to iSatori
 Inc. The trading symbol of the Company on OTCBB is &#147;IFIT&#148;.

Prior to the Merger
 Integrated
was a company with virtually no operations. The Merger was accounted for as the equivalent to the issuance of stock by iSatori
Technologies for the net monetary assets of Integrated. The accompanying financial statements therefore include the consolidated
results of operations of iSatori Technologies and Intergrated for periods subsequent to the Merger
 and iSatori Technologies only
for periods prior to the Merger. References to the financial operations of iSatori Technologies and the Predecessor Company are
noted for the respective reporting periods as noted above. Unless otherwise specifically indicated
 references to the &#147;Company&#148;
(without further qualification) necessarily include iSatori Technologies
 the Predecessor Company
 Integrated and iSatori
 Inc.
for all applicable accounting periods. Since there was no change in the ownership of the business in connection with the Reorganizations
the assets and the liabilities of the Predecessor Company have been recorded on iSatori Technologies&#146; financial statements
at the same amounts at which they were reported on the financial statements of the Predecessor Company. All transactions between
divisions and/or wholly owned subsidiaries of iSatori Technologies or the Predecessor Company have been eliminated in the financial
statements. In addition
 per the operating agreement of the Predecessor Company
 no member was to have been liable for the debts
liabilities or obligations of the Predecessor Company.

The Company is engaged in researching
designing
 developing
 contracting for the manufacture
 marketing
 selling and distributing of various nutritional and dietary
supplement products for the general nutrition market. The &#147;general nutrition market&#148; may include such activities as
body-building
 physique enhancement (increase of lean body mass and decrease in fat mass) and enhanced athletic performance through
increased strength and/or endurance and proper nutrition.

The Company does engage from
time to time in funding of clinical studies with the objective of discovering and/or validating claims of new
 efficacious products
for the Company&#146;s relevant market as well as providing necessary and appropriate substantiation for any claims which the
Company may use in its marketing and advertising. The Company markets products which are under its control and which are in some
way proprietary to the Company. Some of the Company&#146;s products are the subject of trademarks owned by the Company.

The accompanying consolidated
financial statements include the accounts of the Company and the Predecessor Company: LS7; Right Lane; Eat-Smart; Energize; and
Integrated for the respective reporting periods described above.



The accompanying consolidated
financial statements have been prepared on an accrual basis of accounting in accordance with Generally Accepted Accounting Principles
in the United States (&#147;GAAP&#148;). The accompanying consolidated financial statements present the financial position and
results of operations of the Company and include the amounts of the Company as well as the Predecessor Company and all wholly
owned subsidiaries. Accordingly
 all significant intercompany transactions have been eliminated.

Certain amounts in the 2012 consolidated
financial statements have been reclassified to conform to the 2013 presentation. Such reclassifications include moving Coupon
expense from Selling and marketing expense to Product revenue (net of returns and discounts) and moving the income (expense) in
the Change in the value of derivative instruments from Financing expense to Other income (expense) on the consolidated statement
of operations. On the consolidated balance sheet
 Debt issuance costs and Deferred Offering costs have been consolidated into
Deposits and other assets. These had no effect on net income.



The Company considers all highly
liquid debt instruments purchased with an original maturity of three months or less to be cash equivalents. Accordingly
 cash
and cash equivalents consist of petty cash
 checking accounts and money market funds.

As of December 31
 2012
 the
Company invested approximately $966 thousand with Horter Financial Group which
 acted as investment advisor with and into the
Alpha/Pimco Bonds Plus Total Return Fund.

The underlying security matures
in three years. However
 the Company has access and can liquidate the underlying security on 72-hours&#146; notice. Thus
 it
has been classified as a current asset. The investment strategy involves an investment in three separate &#147;power periods&#148;
late October
 late November and late December of each year.

The Company invested $960 thousand
in this fund. As of December 31
 2012
 the Company realized a net asset value gain of approximately $6 thousand. The total portfolio
of the Company had a stated value therefore of $966 thousand. This investment account was closed on February 22
 2013. The Company
realized an additional $7 thousand in net asset value gain up to the time the account was closed.

At December 31
 2013 and December
31
 2012
 the financial instruments of the Company consisted principally of cash and cash equivalents
 investments
 receivables
accounts payable
 certain accrued liabilities and long-term debt. The carrying amount of cash and cash equivalents
 receivables
accounts payable and accrued liabilities approximates their fair value because of the short maturity of these instruments. The
actual and estimated fair values
 respectively
 of the Company&#146;s financial instruments are as follows:

Trade receivables are uncollateralized
customer obligations due under normal trade terms requiring payment generally within 10-60 days from the invoice date. Accounts
are considered delinquent when outstanding for more than seven days past due date. The Company does not have a policy of accruing
interest on past due accounts. Payments on trade receivables are applied as instructed per the customer
 or to the earliest unpaid
invoices. The allowance for doubtful accounts represents an estimate of amounts considered uncollectible and is determined based
on management&#146;s historical collection experience
 adverse situations that may affect the customer&#146;s ability to repay
and prevailing economic conditions. Specific accounts deemed uncollectible are written off periodically with subsequent receipts
on previously written off accounts credited to bad debt expense. The allowance for doubtful accounts is $0 for each of the periods
ended December 31
 2013 and December 31
 2012. Receivables at each of the below respective periods consisted of the following:

 2012 in accrued expenses.

dietary supplements are stated at lower of cost or market on a first-in

The Predecessor Company disposed
of a dormant product line of vitamins in December 2010. As part of the consideration in this divestiture
 the Company received
from the purchaser of this product line an unsecured note in the amount of $170
000. The original note was due to be repaid on
or before March 2014
 where interest accrued principally at an annual rate of 5%
 based upon the initial $170
000 principal and
was payable monthly. As of March 31
 2013
 the note was novated and a new promissory note was issued to reflect a modification
in the payment terms
 which includes no interest. The total amount to be repaid is the open principal amount of $118
608 at December
31
 2013 with $0 interest
 and is due to be repaid on or before May 1
 2017. An allowance in the amount of $25
881 has been recorded
against the aforementioned balance.



Property and equipment are stated
at cost. Depreciation for financial accounting purposes is computed using the straight-line method over the estimated lives of
the respective assets
 ranging from three to ten years. Maintenance and repairs are charged to expense when incurred. When property
and equipment are retired or otherwise disposed of
 the related cost and accumulated depreciation are thereafter removed from
the respective accounts and any gain or loss is credited or charged to income. Total depreciation expense was $83
450 and $76
266
for the years ended December 31
 2013 and 2012
 respectively.

Other Assets and Intangible
Assets

Other assets include intangible
assets which are principally direct television advertising
 websites
 as well as deposits and are included in Deposits and other
Assets. The Company periodically performs reviews of other assets including amortizable intangible and depreciable tangible assets
for impairment purposes using undiscounted cash flow methodology. Factors considered important that may trigger an impairment
of assets review include
 but are not necessarily limited to: significant changes in the manner of the use of its assets involving
its strategy for its overall business; significant negative industry or economic trends; or underperforming business trends. These
reviews may include an analysis of the Company&#146;s current operations and capacity utilization in conjunction with an analysis
of the markets in which the Company&#146;s business is operating.

Intangible assets are discussed
below. Amortization for financial accounting purposes is computed using the straight-line method over the estimated useful lives
of the respective assets which range from three to ten years. Amortization for 2013 and 2012 totaled $11
698 and $3
259
 respectively.
